elements.content: The development of heterogeneous catalysts capable of selectively converting lignin model compounds into products of added value offers an exciting avenue to explore in the production of renewable chemical feedstocks. The use of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) in such chemical transformations relies largely on the presence of accessible open metal sites found within highly porous networks that simultaneously allow for fast transport and strong interactions with desired substrates. Here, we present the first systematic study on the modulation of catalytic performance of a cationic framework, [Cu2(L)­(H2O)2]­(NO3)2·5.5H2O (L = 1,1′-bis­(3,5-dicarboxylatophenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium), achieved through the exchange of anionic guests. Remarkably, the catalytic activity proves to be highly anion-dependent, with a nearly 10-fold increase toward the aerobic C–C bond cleavage of a lignin model compound when different anionic species are incorporated within the MOF. Moreover, we demonstrate that the cationic nature of the MOF, imparted by the incorporation of viologen moieties within the linker, tunes the electrophilicity of the active copper­(II) sites, resulting in stronger interactions with the substrate. As such, the copper-based framework exhibits enhanced catalytic performance when compared to its neutral counterpart, emphasizing the appeal of charged frameworks for use as green heterogeneous catalysts.
elements.clean_text: The development of heterogeneous catalysts capable of selectively converting lignin model compounds into products of added value offers an exciting avenue to explore in the production of renewable chemical feedstocks. The use of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) in such chemical transformations relies largely on the presence of accessible open metal sites found within highly porous networks that simultaneously allow for fast transport and strong interactions with desired substrates. Here, we present the first systematic study on the modulation of catalytic performance of a cationic framework, [Cu2(L)(H2O)2](NO3)2⋅5.5H2O (L = 1,1'-bis(3,5-dicarboxylatophenyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium), achieved through the exchange of anionic guests. Remarkably, the catalytic activity proves to be highly anion-dependent, with a nearly 10-fold increase toward the aerobic C-C bond cleavage of a lignin model compound when different anionic species are incorporated within the MOF. Moreover, we demonstrate that the cationic nature of the MOF, imparted by the incorporation of viologen moieties within the linker, tunes the electrophilicity of the active copper(II) sites, resulting in stronger interactions with the substrate. As such, the copper-based framework exhibits enhanced catalytic performance when compared to its neutral counterpart, emphasizing the appeal of charged frameworks for use as green heterogeneous catalysts.

elements.content: Due to their highly porous and intrinsically tunable nature, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been studied for a number of applications, including gas storage/separations, drug delivery, environmental remediation, solid-state molecular sensing and switching, and for the development of electrically conductive materials, magnets, and heterogeneous catalysts. One of the most appealing features of such systems is the fact that the pore spaces can effectively act as discrete “nanoreactors” to control and promote chemical transformations. Confinement effects, conferred by carefully engineered pore structures, have moreover the ability to render new physicochemical properties and enhance selectivity. These attributes can be of great benefit in the design of heterogeneous catalysts, where metal–substrate interactions are critical in stimulating catalytic activity. Moreover, the high surface areas of MOFs have the potential to maximize the accessibility of catalytically active metal sites, thereby favoring greater reactivity.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Due to their highly porous and intrinsically tunable nature, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been studied for a number of applications, including gas storage/separations, drug delivery, environmental remediation, solid-state molecular sensing and switching, and for the development of electrically conductive materials, magnets, and heterogeneous catalysts. One of the most appealing features of such systems is the fact that the pore spaces can effectively act as discrete "nanoreactors" to control and promote chemical transformations. Confinement effects, conferred by carefully engineered pore structures, have moreover the ability to render new physicochemical properties and enhance selectivity. These attributes can be of great benefit in the design of heterogeneous catalysts, where metal-substrate interactions are critical in stimulating catalytic activity. Moreover, the high surface areas of MOFs have the potential to maximize the accessibility of catalytically active metal sites, thereby favoring greater reactivity.

elements.content: While the judicious selection of building blocks represents a key step in optimizing the chemical behavior of a MOF, molecules encapsulated within pores have also been known to promote and modulate catalytic processes. One common approach relies on the introduction of well-studied catalytically active guest species within the channels or cages of MOFs, enabling highly efficient reactions. In this regard, positively or negatively charged MOFs have the advantage of allowing a straightforward and efficient inclusion of anionic or cationic metal complexes with well-defined catalytic behaviors through ion-metathesis reactions. The exchange of noncoordinating ions in MOFs has previously been shown to impact a number of physical properties, including gas adsorption behaviors and proton conductivity. Thus far, however, tuning the catalytic performance of a charged MOF via replacement of nonactive ionic guest species has yet to be reported.
elements.clean_text: While the judicious selection of building blocks represents a key step in optimizing the chemical behavior of a MOF, molecules encapsulated within pores have also been known to promote and modulate catalytic processes. One common approach relies on the introduction of well-studied catalytically active guest species within the channels or cages of MOFs, enabling highly efficient reactions. In this regard, positively or negatively charged MOFs have the advantage of allowing a straightforward and efficient inclusion of anionic or cationic metal complexes with well-defined catalytic behaviors through ion-metathesis reactions. The exchange of noncoordinating ions in MOFs has previously been shown to impact a number of physical properties, including gas adsorption behaviors and proton conductivity. Thus far, however, tuning the catalytic performance of a charged MOF via  replacement of nonactive ionic guest species has yet to be reported.

elements.content: With this in mind, we sought to assess the effect of guest anions on the catalytic performance of a cationic MOF. To ensure access to open coordination sites, we opted for a previously reported charged framework built from {Cu2 II} “paddlewheel” units linked via a large tetracarboxylic ligand that exhibits high porosity (ca. 68% void space). This MOF, [Cu2(L)­(H2O)2]­(NO3)2·5.5H2O (1), where L = 1,1′-bis­(3,5-dicarboxylatophenyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium (A), is an isoreticular analogue of neutral NOTT-102, (B). In addition to being cost-effective and environmentally friendly, copper­(II)-based materials have previously been investigated for their catalytic activity toward C–C bond cleavage of lignin models. In both NOTT-102 and its charged congener 1, owing to the paddlewheel nodes of the MOFs, the copper­(II) ions adopt a slightly distorted five-coordinate square pyramidal geometry, with the apical position being occupied by a water molecule. These water molecules can readily dissociate, allowing for desired substrate binding to the metal center during catalytic reactions (C). The linker in 1 bears a 4,4′-bipyridinium unit, best known as a viologen motif (vs biphenyl in NOTT-102, B), which is responsible for the overall positive charge of the framework, which is neutralized by two nitrate (NO3 –) counter anions. As a result, 1 exhibits a charge gradient, providing favorable ionic interactions between the anionic guests and the cationic hosts. It was anticipated that the charge, volume, and other features of the included anions could affect the catalytic performance of 1; thus, systematic anion exchange is a prerequisite for probing the effect of nonactive ionic guest species on the catalytic C–C bond cleavage activity.
elements.clean_text: With this in mind, we sought to assess the effect of guest anions on the catalytic performance of a cationic MOF. To ensure access to open coordination sites, we opted for a previously reported charged framework built from {Cu2 II} "paddlewheel" units linked via a large tetracarboxylic ligand that exhibits high porosity (ca. 68% void space). This MOF, [Cu2(L)(H2O)2](NO3)2⋅5.5H2O (1), where L = 1,1'-bis(3,5-dicarboxylatophenyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium (A), is an isoreticular analogue of neutral NOTT-102, (B). In addition to being cost-effective and environmentally friendly, copper(II)-based materials have previously been investigated for their catalytic activity toward C-C bond cleavage of lignin models. In both NOTT-102 and its charged congener 1, owing to the paddlewheel nodes of the MOFs, the copper(II) ions adopt a slightly distorted five-coordinate square pyramidal geometry, with the apical position being occupied by a water molecule. These water molecules can readily dissociate, allowing for desired substrate binding to the metal center during catalytic reactions (C). The linker in 1 bears a 4,4'-bipyridinium unit, best known as a viologen motif (vs biphenyl in NOTT-102, B), which is responsible for the overall positive charge of the framework, which is neutralized by two nitrate (NO3 -) counter anions. As a result, 1 exhibits a charge gradient, providing favorable ionic interactions between the anionic guests and the cationic hosts. It was anticipated that the charge, volume, and other features of the included anions could affect the catalytic performance of 1; thus, systematic anion exchange is a prerequisite for probing the effect of nonactive ionic guest species on the catalytic C-C bond cleavage activity.

elements.content: (A) Structure of 1 viewed along the a-axis; blue = N, red = O, green = CuO5 square pyramidal geometry of the copper­(II) ions. The purple sphere highlights the spherical cavity present in 1 (about 13.2 Å in diameter). (B) Differences in the core motifs of the organic linkers found in 1 (viologen) and NOTT-102 (biphenyl). (C) Coordination environment of the dicopper paddlewheels, showing the exchange of water molecules in the apical position, thus providing accessible open metal sites for catalysis. The arrows represent the dissociation of coordinated water molecules.
elements.clean_text: 1  (A) Structure of 1 viewed along the a-axis; blue = N, red = O, green = CuO5 square pyramidal geometry of the copper(II) ions. The purple sphere highlights the spherical cavity present in 1 (about 13.2 Å in diameter). (B) Differences in the core motifs of the organic linkers found in 1 (viologen) and NOTT-102 (biphenyl). (C) Coordination environment of the dicopper paddlewheels, showing the exchange of water molecules in the apical position, thus providing accessible open metal sites for catalysis. The arrows represent the dissociation of coordinated water molecules.

elements.content: Metal-catalyzed oxidation reactions are of high interest, being used, for instance, to convert lignocellulosic biomass into valuable chemicals such as aldehydes, phenols, and carboxylic acids. Inspired by previous studies conducted on copper-based homogeneous catalysts, we explored the potential of as-synthesized 1 and its exchanged derivatives as heterogeneous catalysts in the aerobic oxidation of lignin. For this purpose, the simple lignin model 1,2-diphenyl-2-methoxyethanol (DPME) was utilized as a versatile substrate, presenting C–C, C–O, O–H, and C–H bonds, thus allowing for catalyst selectivity investigation.
elements.clean_text: Metal-catalyzed oxidation reactions are of high interest, being used, for instance, to convert lignocellulosic biomass into valuable chemicals such as aldehydes, phenols, and carboxylic acids. Inspired by previous studies conducted on copper-based homogeneous catalysts, we explored the potential of as-synthesized 1 and its exchanged derivatives as heterogeneous catalysts in the aerobic oxidation of lignin. For this purpose, the simple lignin model 1,2-diphenyl-2-methoxyethanol (DPME) was utilized as a versatile substrate, presenting C-C, C-O, O-H, and C-H bonds, thus allowing for catalyst selectivity investigation.

elements.content: Our initial studies revealed that the most efficient methodology to achieve anion exchange in 1 is a postsynthetic procedure carried out at room temperature, allowing for insertion of a wide variety of anions. Once obtained, these anion-exchanged frameworks, namely, X–@1 [X– = SCN–, ClO4 –, BF4 –, N­(CN)2 –, BPh4 –, S2O4 2–, and Cr2O7 2–], were examined as heterogeneous catalysts for aerobic C–C bond cleavage of the simple lignin model 1,2-diphenyl-2-methoxyethanol (DPME). Although there are more sophisticated models for the lignin β-O-4 linkage, this model was selected on the basis of previous catalytic selectivity studies. These results were then compared to those using the as-synthesized nitrate-based MOF 1 (NO3 –@1), which was used as the reference catalyst. Herein, we report remarkable effects of anion dependence on C–C bond cleavage catalytic activity and selectivity of the charged MOF, illustrating that even nonactive ionic guests can be effective in enhancing catalytic performance.
elements.clean_text: Our initial studies revealed that the most efficient methodology to achieve anion exchange in 1 is a postsynthetic procedure carried out at room temperature, allowing for insertion of a wide variety of anions. Once obtained, these anion-exchanged frameworks, namely, X-@1 [X- = SCN-, ClO4 -, BF4 -, N(CN)2 -, BPh4 -, S2O4 2-, and Cr2O7 2-], were examined as heterogeneous catalysts for aerobic C-C bond cleavage of the simple lignin model 1,2-diphenyl-2-methoxyethanol (DPME). Although there are more sophisticated models for the lignin β-O-4 linkage, this model was selected on the basis of previous catalytic selectivity studies. These results were then compared to those using the as-synthesized nitrate-based MOF 1 (NO3 -@1), which was used as the reference catalyst. Herein, we report remarkable effects of anion dependence on C-C bond cleavage catalytic activity and selectivity of the charged MOF, illustrating that even nonactive ionic guests can be effective in enhancing catalytic performance.

elements.content: The experiments were carried out by immersing microcrystals of 1 in dimethylformamide (DMF) solutions of the following salts at room temperature: (n-Bu4N)­SCN, (n-Bu4N)­ClO4, (n-Bu4N)­BF4, Na­[N­(CN)2], Na­(BPh4), Na2S2O4, and K2Cr2O7 (see the Supporting Information for details). The efficiency of the heterogeneous phase metathesis processes was systematically confirmed by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy measurements (A), showing characteristic bands belonging to NO3 –, SCN–, ClO4 –, BPh4 –, BF4 –, and N­(CN)2 – anions at 1332, 2089, 1095, 707, 1058, and 2170 cm–1, respectively. Insertion of anions lacking diagnostic/clear IR bands, like Cr2O7 2– and S2O4 2–, was confirmed indirectly through modification of the shoulder at 1332 cm–1, assigned to one of the N–O asymmetric stretching vibrations of NO3 –. Crystal structure retention of all tested anion-exchanged MOFs was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; B). Complete FT-IR kinetic studies are presented in the Supporting Information (Figures S1–S7).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Anion Exchange Study

The experiments were carried out by immersing microcrystals of 1 in dimethylformamide (DMF) solutions of the following salts at room temperature: (n-Bu4N)SCN, (n-Bu4N)ClO4, (n-Bu4N)BF4, Na[N(CN)2], Na(BPh4), Na2S2O4, and K2Cr2O7 (see the Supporting Information for details). The efficiency of the heterogeneous phase metathesis processes was systematically confirmed by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy measurements (A), showing characteristic bands belonging to NO3 -, SCN-, ClO4 -, BPh4 -, BF4 -, and N(CN)2 - anions at 1332, 2089, 1095, 707, 1058, and 2170 cm-1, respectively. Insertion of anions lacking diagnostic/clear IR bands, like Cr2O7 2- and S2O4 2-, was confirmed indirectly through modification of the shoulder at 1332 cm-1, assigned to one of the N-O asymmetric stretching vibrations of NO3 -. Crystal structure retention of all tested anion-exchanged MOFs was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; B). Complete FT-IR kinetic studies are presented in the Supporting Information (Figures S1-S7).

elements.content: (A) FT-IR spectra of as-synthesized 1 (NO3 –@1) and its anion-exchanged derivatives, highlighting selected bands of the corresponding anions. Inclusion of anions without any characteristic bands was monitored by the disappearance of the shoulder near 1300 cm–1 (highlighted green rectangle), assigned to an N–O asymmetric stretching vibration of the nitrate anion. (B) PXRD patterns of as-synthesized 1 and its anion-exchanged derivatives. (C) 15N magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) of 15NO3 –@1 before and after exchange with ClO4 – under the same spectroscopic conditions.
elements.clean_text: 2  (A) FT-IR spectra of as-synthesized 1 (NO3 -@1) and its anion-exchanged derivatives, highlighting selected bands of the corresponding anions. Inclusion of anions without any characteristic bands was monitored by the disappearance of the shoulder near 1300 cm-1 (highlighted green rectangle), assigned to an N-O asymmetric stretching vibration of the nitrate anion. (B) PXRD patterns of as-synthesized 1 and its anion-exchanged derivatives. (C) 15N magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) of 15NO3 -@1 before and after  exchange with ClO4 - under the same spectroscopic conditions.

elements.content: The exchange of NO3 – anions by SCN– and especially N­(CN)2 – was found to induce loss in crystallinity, potentially attributed to a partial collapse of the framework due to the highly nucleophilic character of these anions, which may lead to distortions around the copper­(II) centers. The shift of the main peak observed in the PXRD pattern of N­(CN)2 –@1 (2θ = 5.07°) compared to NO3 –@1 (2θ = 5.25°) (B) provides indisputable proof of such structural modifications triggered by anion metathesis. Loss of crystallinity was also noticed for S2O4 2–@1 and Cr2O7 2–@1, likely caused by a local charge imbalance (e.g., dianion vs monoanion) that destabilizes the framework.
elements.clean_text: The exchange of NO3 - anions by SCN- and especially N(CN)2 - was found to induce loss in crystallinity, potentially attributed to a partial collapse of the framework due to the highly nucleophilic character of these anions, which may lead to distortions around the copper(II) centers. The shift of the main peak observed in the PXRD pattern of N(CN)2 -@1 (2θ = 5.07°) compared to NO3 -@1 (2θ = 5.25°) (B) provides indisputable proof of such structural modifications triggered by anion metathesis. Loss of crystallinity was also noticed for S2O4 2-@1 and Cr2O7 2-@1, likely caused by a local charge imbalance (e.g., dianion vs monoanion) that destabilizes the framework.

elements.content: A complementary 15N magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) study was performed to assess the extent of anion exchange within 1. Initial studies were carried out with ClO4 – anions due to the fast exchange kinetics observed in the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) experiments. Enrichment of 1 with 15NO3 – was performed using multiple treatments with an NH4 15NO3 solution (see Supporting Information for details). As can be seen in C, the 15N MAS NMR spectrum of 15NO3 –@1 displays a nonsymmetrical signal attributed to the 15NO3 – guests residing in different environments within the pores. After exhaustive exchange achieved using solutions of (n-Bu4N)­ClO4 in DMF at room temperature, the intensity of the 15N MAS NMR resonance decreased to ca. 65% of that due to 15NO3 –@1, indicating that ca. 35% of the nitrate anions were exchanged (see Supporting Information). Based on this result and considering the formula of 1, the exchanged ClO4 –@1 can be formulated as [Cu2(L)­(H2O)2]­(NO3)1.3(ClO4)0.7·5.5H2O. The incomplete exchange of nitrate with perchlorate anions within 1, even after several hours of soaking in fresh solutions of (n-Bu4N)­ClO4, can presumably be related to different environments surrounding the nitrate anions inside the pores. In fact, 1 presents at least two nonequivalent vicinities imposed by the two types of cages observed in the structure that are alternately stacked in a 1:1 ratio. The spherical cage (Cu12L12) is about 13.2 Å in diameter, while the large rod-shaped cage (Cu24L6) is about 10.1 × 31.8 Å2 (Figure S8). The small shift of the single 15N NMR resonance from 327 to 330 ppm may be indicative of such preferential exchange imposed by the nitrate environment. Unfortunately, the exact location of the nitrate anions could not be determined during structural refinement; thus, they were removed by the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON, along with several guest solvent molecules. However, the homogeneous distribution of ClO4 – guests in the material ClO4 –@1 was demonstrated through Cl mapping using microanalysis/scanning electron microscopy (EDS/SEM) on a flat piece of crystal of the material (Figure S9).
elements.clean_text: A complementary 15N magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) study was performed to assess the extent of anion exchange within 1. Initial studies were carried out with ClO4 - anions due to the fast exchange kinetics observed in the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) experiments. Enrichment of 1 with 15NO3 - was performed using multiple treatments with an NH4 15NO3 solution (see Supporting Information for details). As can be seen in C, the 15N MAS NMR spectrum of 15NO3 -@1 displays a nonsymmetrical signal attributed to the 15NO3 - guests residing in different environments within the pores. After exhaustive exchange achieved using solutions of (n-Bu4N)ClO4 in DMF at room temperature, the intensity of the 15N MAS NMR resonance decreased to ca. 65% of that due to 15NO3 -@1, indicating that ca. 35% of the nitrate anions were exchanged (see Supporting Information). Based on this result and considering the formula of 1, the exchanged ClO4 -@1 can be formulated as [Cu2(L)(H2O)2](NO3)1.3(ClO4)0.7⋅5.5H2O. The incomplete exchange of nitrate with perchlorate anions within 1, even after several hours of soaking in fresh solutions of (n-Bu4N)ClO4, can presumably be related to different environments surrounding the nitrate anions inside the pores. In fact, 1 presents at least two nonequivalent vicinities imposed by the two types of cages observed in the structure that are alternately stacked in a 1:1 ratio. The spherical cage (Cu12L12) is about 13.2 Å in diameter, while the large rod-shaped cage (Cu24L6) is about 10.1 × 31.8 Å2 (Figure S8). The small shift of the single 15N NMR resonance from 327 to 330 ppm may be indicative of such preferential exchange imposed by the nitrate environment. Unfortunately, the exact location of the nitrate anions could not be determined during structural refinement; thus, they were removed by the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON, along with several guest solvent molecules. However, the homogeneous distribution of ClO4 - guests in the material ClO4 -@1 was demonstrated through Cl mapping using microanalysis/scanning electron microscopy (EDS/SEM) on a flat piece of crystal of the material (Figure S9).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of all anion-exchanged samples were conducted under a nitrogen atmosphere, except for ClO4 –@1 due to its energetic potential (Figure S10). Slight differences in weight loss profiles were observed but none of these data suggested a specific anion-driven stabilization of 1. We also found that like as-synthesized NO3 –@1, all of the anion-exchanged analogues were unstable in aqueous media or after desolvation. Solvent exchange using CHCl3 followed by air-drying led to the collapse of the crystalline structures as probed by PRXD for MOFs SCN–@1, ClO4 –@1, BPh4 –@1, Cr2O7 2–@1, and BF4 –@1 (Figure S11). We also characterized SCN–@1 and Cr2O7 2–@1 by nitrogen adsorption–desorption and observed the same collapse reported for as-synthesized 1 (Figure S12).
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of all anion-exchanged samples were conducted under a nitrogen atmosphere, except for ClO4 -@1 due to its energetic potential (Figure S10). Slight differences in weight loss profiles were observed but none of these data suggested a specific anion-driven stabilization of 1. We also found that like as-synthesized NO3 -@1, all of the anion-exchanged analogues were unstable in aqueous media or after desolvation. Solvent exchange using CHCl3 followed by air-drying led to the collapse of the crystalline structures as probed by PRXD for MOFs SCN-@1, ClO4 -@1, BPh4 -@1, Cr2O7 2-@1, and BF4 -@1 (Figure S11). We also characterized SCN-@1 and Cr2O7 2-@1 by nitrogen adsorption-desorption and observed the same collapse reported for  as-synthesized 1 (Figure S12).

elements.content:
Nevertheless, the highly porous nature of these materials and the presence of accessible copper­(II) sites encouraged us to explore their potential as heterogeneous catalysts in dry organic solvents.

Aerobic Oxidation of DPME

The first step in the catalytic tests involved soaking ground crystals of 1 in toluene or pyridine, two commonly employed solvents for the aerobic oxidation of lignin models. Prior to this, solvent exchange using fresh aliquots of toluene or pyridine was made (see Supporting Information for details). When pyridine was used, the formation of a green solution during the solvent exchange was attributed to the partial degradation of 1 resulting from copper leaching. Further support for this assumption came from 1H NMR spectroscopy measurements consistent with the presence of paramagnetic copper­(II) species.
elements.clean_text:
Nevertheless, the highly porous nature of these materials and the presence of accessible copper(II) sites encouraged us to explore their potential as heterogeneous catalysts in dry organic solvents.

Aerobic Oxidation of DPME

The first step in the catalytic tests involved soaking ground crystals of 1 in toluene or pyridine, two commonly employed solvents for the aerobic oxidation of lignin models. Prior to this, solvent exchange using fresh aliquots of toluene or pyridine was made (see Supporting Information for details). When pyridine was used, the formation of a green solution during the solvent exchange was attributed to the partial degradation of 1 resulting from copper leaching. Further support for this assumption came from 1H NMR spectroscopy measurements consistent with the presence of paramagnetic copper(II) species.

elements.content: Aerobic oxidation of DPME was performed using NO3 –@1 (20 mol % Cu) in toluene and pyridine at 100 °C. These reactions were conducted in capped glass vials and monitored by 1H NMR spectroscopy after 24 and 48 h (Figure S13). The best results were obtained in toluene, yielding higher substrate conversion while preserving the integrity of the MOF. Moreover, toluene presents a suitable 1H NMR spectral window, allowing for accurate monitoring of the disappearance of substrate peaks (4–5 ppm) and the emergence of a C–H resonance at 10 ppm attributed to benzaldehyde, one of the DPME oxidation products (A and S13).
elements.clean_text: Aerobic oxidation of DPME was performed using NO3 -@1 (20 mol % Cu) in toluene and pyridine at 100 °C. These reactions were conducted in capped glass vials and monitored by 1H NMR spectroscopy after 24 and 48 h (Figure S13). The best results were obtained in toluene, yielding higher substrate conversion while preserving the integrity of the MOF. Moreover, toluene presents a suitable 1H NMR spectral window, allowing for accurate monitoring of the disappearance of substrate peaks (4-5 ppm) and the emergence of a C-H resonance at 10 ppm attributed to benzaldehyde, one of the DPME oxidation products (A and S13).

elements.content: (A) Schematic representation of the aerobic oxidation of DPME using CuII-MOFs. (B) Catalysts tested in aerobic oxidation of DPME with respective conversion and yields of benzaldehyde (I) and methyl benzoate (II) estimated from the integration of aromatic protons (see details in Figure B).
elements.clean_text: 3  (A) Schematic representation of the aerobic oxidation of DPME using CuII-MOFs. (B) Catalysts tested in aerobic oxidation of DPME with respective conversion and yields of benzaldehyde (I) and methyl benzoate (II) estimated from the integration of aromatic protons (see details in Figure  B).

elements.content: Aerobic oxidation of DPME was also performed using the anion-exchanged MOFs (20 mol % Cu) in toluene, at 100 °C for 48 h (B). These reactions were conducted under the same conditions, and no oxygen flow was required to convert the starting material into products. This approach is methodologically advanced when compared to most previously reported aerobic catalyzed reactions, including those employing homogeneous or heterogeneous processes. A CuII-MOF was used by Garcia et al. as a catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde, but an oxyl radical initiator was needed as a cocatalyst, with some limitations in terms of catalyst stability.
elements.clean_text: Aerobic oxidation of DPME was also performed using the anion-exchanged MOFs (20 mol % Cu) in toluene, at 100 °C for 48 h (B). These reactions were conducted under the same conditions, and no oxygen flow was required to convert the starting material into products. This approach is methodologically advanced when compared to most previously reported aerobic catalyzed reactions, including those employing homogeneous or heterogeneous processes. A CuII-MOF was used by Garcia et al. as a catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde, but an oxyl radical initiator was needed as a cocatalyst, with some limitations in terms of catalyst stability.

elements.content: The MOF-catalyzed aerobic oxidation of the lignin model DPME yielded benzaldehyde, methyl benzoate, and methanol (A) primarily, with no detected overoxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid. The products were identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy ( and S14) considering the peaks observed at approximately δ 4.94 ppm (substrate C–H proton), δ 10.08 ppm (benzaldehyde CHO proton), and δ 3.95 ppm (methyl benzoate OMe protons). Methanol was identified by adding a drop of the solvent to the NMR tubes containing the reaction products and observing the spike of one of the pre-existing low-intense peaks at δ 3.51 ppm (methanol CH3 protons; Figure S15). Conversion and selectivity were estimated from integration of aromatic proton NMR resonances (B). Additional unidentified resonances (B) arise presumably from higher molecular weight condensation byproducts as they were not observed by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analysis (Figure S16).
elements.clean_text: The MOF-catalyzed aerobic oxidation of the lignin model DPME yielded benzaldehyde, methyl benzoate, and methanol (A) primarily, with no detected overoxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid. The products were identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy ( and S14) considering the peaks observed at approximately δ 4.94 ppm (substrate C-H proton), δ 10.08 ppm (benzaldehyde CHO proton), and δ 3.95 ppm (methyl benzoate OMe protons). Methanol was identified by adding a drop of the solvent to the NMR tubes containing the reaction products and observing the spike of one of the pre-existing low-intense peaks at δ 3.51 ppm (methanol CH3 protons; Figure S15). Conversion and selectivity were estimated from integration of aromatic proton NMR resonances (B). Additional unidentified resonances (B) arise presumably from higher molecular weight condensation byproducts as they were not observed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) analysis (Figure S16).

elements.content: Zoom-in of the 1H NMR spectra (A) in the region between 9.9 and 10.2 ppm, showing the benzaldehyde C­(O)H resonance; (B) in the region between 7.85 and 8.20 ppm, showing aromatic multiplets due to benzaldehyde (7.88–7.92 ppm), methyl benzoate (7.98–8.02 ppm), and other minor oxidation products; and (C) in the region between 3.3 and 5.0 ppm, showing the C–H resonances of the two DPME diastereomers. Peaks observed at 3.9 ppm are due to OCH3 protons from the ester product methyl benzoate. The control experiment was performed using DPME in toluene in the absence of 1 (100 °C, 48 h).
elements.clean_text: 4  Zoom-in of the 1H NMR spectra (A) in the region between 9.9 and 10.2 ppm, showing the benzaldehyde C(O)H resonance; (B) in the region between 7.85 and 8.20 ppm, showing aromatic multiplets due to benzaldehyde (7.88-7.92 ppm), methyl benzoate (7.98-8.02 ppm), and other minor oxidation products; and (C) in the region between 3.3 and 5.0 ppm, showing the C-H resonances of the two DPME diastereomers. Peaks observed at 3.9 ppm are due to OCH3 protons from the ester product methyl benzoate. The control experiment was performed using DPME in toluene in the absence of 1 (100 °C, 48 h).

elements.content: A notable feature of 1 is the presence of open metal sites on the copper­(II) paddlewheels in the pores, enabling a selective transformation of the substrate (see C). 1 thus appears to act via two different pathways: the first one is a C–O bond cleavage followed by a C–C bond cleavage yielding benzaldehyde and methanol in a 2:1 ratio (, path 1), and the second one involves a direct C–C bond cleavage, yielding benzaldehyde and methyl benzoate in a 1:1 ratio (, path 2). Values presented in B point to a preference for path 1 (as evidenced by the >1 benzaldehyde to methyl benzoate ratio), except for Cr2O7 2–@1, evidencing the high selectivity of these MOF catalysts for C–O bond cleavage compared to direct C–C bond cleavage. Previous work suggests that a single electron transfer pathway likely operates in similar Cu systems. It is also important to note that the preferred pathway does not yield water, which could potentially deactivate the MOFs.
elements.clean_text: A notable feature of 1 is the presence of open metal sites on the copper(II) paddlewheels in the pores, enabling a selective transformation of the substrate (see C). 1 thus appears to act via two different pathways: the first one is a C-O bond cleavage followed by a C-C bond cleavage yielding benzaldehyde and methanol in a 2:1 ratio (, path 1), and the second one involves a direct C-C bond cleavage, yielding benzaldehyde and methyl benzoate in a 1:1 ratio (, path 2). Values presented in B point to a preference for path 1 (as evidenced by the >1 benzaldehyde to methyl benzoate ratio), except for Cr2O7 2-@1, evidencing the high selectivity of these MOF catalysts for C-O bond cleavage compared to direct C-C bond cleavage. Previous work suggests that a single electron transfer pathway likely operates in similar Cu systems. It is also important to note that the preferred pathway does not yield water, which could potentially deactivate the MOFs.

<caption>
<title>Possible Pathways for the Aerobic
Oxidation of 1,2-Diphenyl-2-methoxyethanol
in the Presence of MOFs</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" position="float" xlink:href="am0c19212_0007.tif"></graphic>

elements.clean_text: 1  Possible Pathways for the Aerobic Oxidation of 1,2-Diphenyl-2-methoxyethanol in the Presence of MOFs

elements.content: Copper-based catalytic oxidation of secondary alcohol substrates like the model used herein could also afford ketones through C–H bond cleavage (, path 3). When using a CuII-based catalyst in aerobic oxidation of lignin models, Cao et al. identified the ketone as an intermediate, which then undergoes oxidative C–C bond cleavage. On the other hand, Han et al. reported the aerobic oxidation of secondary alcohols to the corresponding ketones with no further bond cleavage. In our case, very low ketone-related 1H NMR resonance peaks were observed when NO3 –@1 and ClO4 –@1 were the catalysts (Figure S17), corroborating the selectivity of the MOF catalysts toward C–O bond cleavage followed by C–C bond cleavage.
elements.clean_text: Copper-based catalytic oxidation of secondary alcohol substrates like the model used herein could also afford ketones through C-H bond cleavage (, path 3). When using a CuII-based catalyst in aerobic oxidation of lignin models, Cao et al. identified the ketone as an intermediate, which then undergoes oxidative C-C bond cleavage. On the other hand, Han et al. reported the aerobic oxidation of secondary alcohols to the corresponding ketones with no further bond cleavage. In our case, very low ketone-related 1H NMR resonance peaks were observed when NO3 -@1 and ClO4 -@1 were the catalysts (Figure S17), corroborating the selectivity of the MOF catalysts toward C-O bond cleavage followed by C-C bond cleavage.

elements.content: While as-synthesized NO3 –@1 proved to be active in the aerobic oxidation of DPME, complete substrate conversion could not be achieved within 2 days at 100 °C (B, entry 6, C, and S14). For the anion-exchanged MOFs, peak performance was observed for ClO4 –@1 with >95% conversion of the substrate (B, entry 8, , and S14). In fact, the inclusion of ClO4 – in 1 represents a nearly 10-fold enhancement in the catalytic activity over the SCN–@1 derivative. This clearly highlights the importance of counterions in the catalytic performance of charged MOFs and provides a relatively simple method of enhancing reactivity through tunability. Improved performance of perchlorate salts used as additives or cocatalysts in aerobic oxidation reactions has already been observed, although there are no reports toward C–C bond cleavage for lignin model compounds. The weak coordination ability of perchlorate anions presumably facilitates the formation of metal–substrate bonds, which accounts for the superior performance of Cu­(ClO4)2 as a homogeneous catalyst when compared to other copper­(II) salts.
elements.clean_text: While as-synthesized NO3 -@1 proved to be active in the aerobic oxidation of DPME, complete substrate conversion could not be achieved within 2 days at 100 °C (B, entry 6, C, and S14). For the anion-exchanged MOFs, peak performance was observed for ClO4 -@1 with >95% conversion of the substrate (B, entry 8, , and S14). In fact, the inclusion of ClO4 - in 1 represents a nearly 10-fold enhancement in the catalytic activity over the SCN-@1 derivative. This clearly highlights the importance of counterions in the catalytic performance of charged MOFs and provides a relatively simple method of enhancing reactivity through tunability. Improved performance of perchlorate salts used as additives or cocatalysts in aerobic oxidation reactions has already been observed, although there are no reports toward C-C bond cleavage for lignin model compounds. The weak coordination ability of perchlorate anions presumably facilitates the formation of metal-substrate bonds, which accounts for the superior performance of Cu(ClO4)2 as a homogeneous catalyst when compared to other copper(II) salts.

elements.content: We can compare the activity and selectivity of our Cu MOF catalysts for aerobic C–C bond cleavage of DPME with other Cu- and V-catalysts employed under homogeneous conditions. For instance, CuCl/TEMPO in pyridine yielded benzaldehyde (84%) and methyl benzoate (88%) with 92% conversion after 48 h at 100 °C. However, this reaction utilized oxygen instead of air and multiple catalyst additions due to its low stability. Using V-complex (dipic)­VV(O)­(OiPr), the ketone (benzoin methyl ether) was detected as one of the intermediates, affording methyl benzoate (84%) and the overoxidized product benzoic acid (85%), with low yields of benzaldehyde (9%). In dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), the overoxidation to benzoic acid was also detected. Therefore, we believe that the straightforward separation of the solid ClO4 –@1 from the reaction products and its selectivity toward benzaldehyde represent significant advances.
elements.clean_text: We can compare the activity and selectivity of our Cu MOF catalysts for aerobic C-C bond cleavage of DPME with other Cu- and V-catalysts employed under homogeneous conditions. For instance, CuCl/TEMPO in pyridine yielded benzaldehyde (84%) and methyl benzoate (88%) with 92% conversion after 48 h at 100 °C. However, this reaction utilized oxygen instead of air and multiple catalyst additions due to its low stability. Using  V-complex (dipic)VV(O)(OiPr), the ketone (benzoin methyl ether) was detected as one of the intermediates, affording methyl benzoate (84%) and the overoxidized product benzoic acid (85%), with low yields of benzaldehyde (9%). In dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), the overoxidation to benzoic acid was also detected. Therefore, we believe that the straightforward separation of the solid ClO4 -@1 from the reaction products and its selectivity toward benzaldehyde represent significant advances.

elements.content: The peak performance of ClO4 –@1 suggests a synergistic effect between the active copper center and the hosted perchlorate ion. Following dissociation of the water molecules bound to the copper paddlewheels in 1 (see C), the more nucleophilic anions such as SCN– and N­(CN)2 – can presumably compete with the substrate for binding to Cu, thus hampering oxidation of the latter (B, entries 1 and 2, C, and S14). Thus, the nucleophilic character of the different anions tested in this study can be classified as follows: SCN– > N­(CN)2 – > BF4 – ≈ BPh4 – > NO3 – ≈ S2O4 2– > Cr2O7 2– > ClO4 – (B). The low activity observed for the weakly coordinating anion BPh4 – is also attributed to its larger size (see Tables S1 and S2), potentially hindering access of the substrate to Cu sites. In contrast, the poor activity of BF4 –@1 may reflect the increased ability of fluorine atoms to donate electron density to copper as compared to some of the oxoanions.
elements.clean_text: The peak performance of ClO4 -@1 suggests a synergistic effect between the active copper center and the hosted perchlorate ion. Following dissociation of the water molecules bound to the copper paddlewheels in 1 (see C), the more nucleophilic anions such as SCN- and N(CN)2 - can presumably compete with the substrate for binding to Cu, thus hampering oxidation of the latter (B, entries 1 and 2, C, and S14). Thus, the nucleophilic character of the different anions tested in this study can be classified as follows: SCN- > N(CN)2 - > BF4 - ~ BPh4 - > NO3 - ~ S2O4 2- > Cr2O7 2- > ClO4 - (B). The low activity observed for the weakly coordinating anion BPh4 - is also attributed to its larger size (see Tables S1 and S2), potentially hindering  access of the substrate to Cu sites. In contrast, the poor activity of BF4 -@1 may reflect the increased ability of fluorine atoms to donate electron density to copper as compared to some of the oxoanions.

elements.content: More interestingly, the oxidation selectivity also depended strongly on the nature of the exchanged anion with the observed benzaldehyde to ester ratio as follows: BF4 – > BPh4 – > ClO4 – ≈ SCN– ≈ N­(CN)2 – > NO3 – ≈ S2O4 2– ≫ Cr2O7 2– (B). Indeed, the latter actually produced more ester than benzaldehyde, in addition to two unidentified products.
elements.clean_text: More interestingly, the oxidation selectivity also depended strongly on the nature of the exchanged anion with the observed benzaldehyde to ester ratio as follows: BF4 - > BPh4 - > ClO4 - ~ SCN- ~ N(CN)2 - > NO3 - ~ S2O4 2- ≫ Cr2O7 2- (B). Indeed, the latter actually produced more ester than benzaldehyde, in addition to two unidentified products.

elements.content: To probe whether the concentration of exogenous ClO4 – in the reaction medium could play a role in the catalytic process, experiments were conducted under the same conditions using NO3 –@1 in the presence of different concentrations of (n-Bu4N)­ClO4 (0.03, 0.06, 0.12, and 0.24 mol L–1) (A; for details see Supporting Information). The modest catalytic activity observed under these conditions suggests that (i) limited diffusion of ClO4 – occurs within the channels of 1 during the catalytic reactions, and (ii) the presence of an external bulky n-Bu4N+ cation surrounding the opening of the MOF channels can prevent the loading of the substrate, and as a consequence, its conversion. The limited ClO4 – diffusion during the reaction can be explained by the much lower dielectric constant of toluene (2.38) compared to DMF (36.71), the solvent used during the anion exchange studies. This is an important property of a solvent that provides ionic mobility during charged guest exchanges. Finally, a control experiment performed with (n-Bu4N)­ClO4 in the absence of 1 did not lead to any conversion of the substrate (Figure S18), showing that ClO4 – itself is not active for the aerobic oxidation of this lignin model.
elements.clean_text: To probe whether the concentration of exogenous ClO4 - in the reaction medium could play a role in the catalytic process, experiments were conducted under the same conditions using NO3 -@1 in the presence of different concentrations of (n-Bu4N)ClO4 (0.03, 0.06, 0.12, and 0.24 mol L-1) (A; for details see Supporting Information). The modest catalytic activity observed under these conditions suggests that (i) limited diffusion of ClO4 - occurs within the channels of 1 during the catalytic reactions, and (ii) the presence of an external bulky n-Bu4N+ cation surrounding the opening of the MOF channels can prevent the loading of the substrate, and as a consequence, its conversion. The limited ClO4 - diffusion during the reaction can be explained by the much lower dielectric constant of toluene (2.38) compared to DMF (36.71), the solvent used during the anion exchange studies. This is an important property of a solvent that provides ionic mobility during charged guest exchanges. Finally, a control experiment performed with (n-Bu4N)ClO4 in the absence of 1 did not lead to any conversion of the substrate (Figure S18), showing that ClO4 - itself is not active for the aerobic oxidation of this lignin model.

elements.content: (A) Comparison of catalytic performance toward aerobic oxidation of DPME using ClO4 –@1, and NO3 –@1 in the presence of four different concentrations of NBu4ClO4 (0.03, 0.06, 0.12, and 0.24 mol L–1). (B) Comparison of catalytic performance toward aerobic oxidation of DPME using (i) ClO4 –@1 in the presence of 4-acetamido-TEMPO (Ac-TEMPO), (ii) ClO4 –@1 in the presence of TEMPO, (iii) the neutral analogue of 1, NOTT-102, and (iv) ClO4 –@1. The reactions were monitored by means of the benzaldehyde/substrate ratio estimated from the integration of relevant 1H NMR resonances.
elements.clean_text: 5  (A) Comparison of catalytic performance toward aerobic oxidation of DPME using ClO4 -@1, and NO3 -@1 in the presence of four different concentrations of NBu4ClO4 (0.03, 0.06, 0.12, and 0.24 mol L-1). (B) Comparison of catalytic performance toward aerobic oxidation of DPME using (i) ClO4 -@1 in the presence of 4-acetamido-TEMPO (Ac-TEMPO), (ii) ClO4 -@1 in the presence of TEMPO, (iii) the neutral analogue of 1, NOTT-102, and (iv) ClO4 -@1. The reactions were monitored by means of the benzaldehyde/substrate ratio estimated from the integration of relevant 1H NMR resonances.

elements.content: After the first use in catalysis, ClO4 –@1 was centrifuged, and the resultant colorless filtrate was separated. The remaining crystals of ClO4 –@1 were washed several times with toluene and characterized by FT-IR and PXRD, confirming the retention of its structure (Figures S19A,B and S20). The recovered material was then reused under the same conditions (for details see Supporting Information), exhibiting a significant loss of activity with 58% conversion (Figure S21), likely due to poisoning of copper­(II) sites in the MOF by water, one of the reaction products (Figure S19C,D). Nevertheless, the reconditioned ClO4 –@1 sample was found to exhibit better activity than, for example, freshly prepared BF4 –@1. In contrast, adding a new substrate loading to the colorless filtrate gave no substrate conversion after 48 h, confirming that the observed catalysis is due to the solid MOF instead of leached species in the solution (Figure S22).
elements.clean_text: After the first use in catalysis, ClO4 -@1 was centrifuged, and the resultant colorless filtrate was separated. The remaining crystals of ClO4 -@1 were washed several times with toluene and characterized by FT-IR and PXRD, confirming the retention of its structure (Figures S19A,B and S20). The recovered material was then reused under the same conditions (for details see Supporting Information), exhibiting a significant loss of activity with 58% conversion (Figure S21), likely due to poisoning of copper(II) sites in the MOF by water, one of the reaction products (Figure S19C,D). Nevertheless, the reconditioned ClO4 -@1 sample was found to exhibit better activity than, for example, freshly prepared BF4 -@1. In contrast, adding a new substrate loading to the colorless filtrate gave no substrate conversion after 48 h, confirming that the observed catalysis is due to the solid MOF instead of leached species in the solution (Figure S22).

elements.content: The free oxyl radicals 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) or 4-acetamido-TEMPO (20 mol %), often employed as oxidation cocatalysts with Cu, were also added to the reaction medium in an attempt to accelerate the reaction catalyzed by ClO4 –@1. However, such addition gave a significant decrease in the reaction rate (B), suggesting that the oxyl radicals are also competing for the copper sites within the MOF pores, thus hindering substrate access.
elements.clean_text: The free oxyl radicals 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl (TEMPO) or 4-acetamido-TEMPO (20 mol %), often employed as oxidation cocatalysts with Cu, were also added to the reaction medium in an attempt to accelerate the reaction catalyzed by ClO4 -@1. However, such addition gave a significant decrease in the reaction rate (B), suggesting that the oxyl radicals are also competing for the copper sites within the MOF pores, thus hindering substrate access.

elements.content: To assess the influence of the viologen-based linker and cationic nature of the MOF, the neutral analogue of 1 designated as NOTT-102 was tested under the same conditions. This study revealed that NOTT-102 also displays some catalytic activity (B), supporting our conclusion that the active sites for catalysis are isolated copper­(II) centers. However, the catalytic performance of NOTT-102 was significantly lower than that of ClO4 –@1 (B), confirming the synergy of copper­(II) sites, perchlorate, and oxygen (from air) in the confined environment provided by the cationic MOF. The viologen motifs in 1 are likely acting as electron-withdrawing groups on the terminal carboxylates, making them weaker ligands to the copper­(II) centers, which in part explains the lower stability of 1 in water. For catalytic purposes, the presence of viologen increases the electrophilicity of copper centers allowing a better interaction of copper with the substrate, leading to its higher conversion in comparison to NOTT-102.
elements.clean_text: To assess the influence of the viologen-based linker and  cationic nature of the MOF, the neutral analogue of 1 designated as NOTT-102  was tested under the same conditions. This study revealed that NOTT-102 also displays some catalytic activity (B), supporting our conclusion that the active sites for catalysis are isolated copper(II) centers. However, the catalytic performance of NOTT-102 was significantly lower than that of ClO4 -@1 (B), confirming the synergy of copper(II) sites, perchlorate, and oxygen (from air) in the confined environment provided by the cationic MOF. The viologen motifs in 1 are likely acting as electron-withdrawing groups on the terminal carboxylates, making them weaker ligands to the copper(II) centers, which in part explains the lower stability of 1 in water. For catalytic purposes, the presence of viologen increases the electrophilicity of copper centers allowing a better interaction of copper with the substrate, leading to its higher conversion in comparison to NOTT-102.

elements.content: The above results demonstrate that 1, a cationic metal–organic framework featuring accessible open metal sites along the copper­(II) paddlewheel axis, can readily undergo anion-exchange reactions using a procedure that is both easily modifiable and functional at room temperature. The viologen motif inserted in the ligand template generates a charge-gradient, providing favorable ionic interactions between the anionic guests and the host framework. Furthermore, utilization of the anion-exchanged MOFs toward C–C bond cleavage using a lignin model as substrate and oxygen as oxidant showed a notable anion-dependent activity and selectivity. All of the tested anion-exchanged MOFs, except Cr2O7 2–@1, were more selective for the C–O followed by C–C bond cleavage pathway.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The above results demonstrate that 1, a cationic metal-organic framework featuring accessible open metal sites along the copper(II) paddlewheel axis, can readily undergo anion-exchange reactions using a procedure that is both easily modifiable and functional at room temperature. The viologen motif inserted in the ligand template generates a charge-gradient, providing favorable ionic interactions between the anionic guests and the host framework. Furthermore, utilization of the anion-exchanged MOFs toward C-C bond cleavage using a lignin model as substrate and oxygen as oxidant showed a notable anion-dependent activity and selectivity. All of the tested anion-exchanged MOFs, except Cr2O7 2-@1, were more selective for the C-O followed by C-C bond cleavage pathway.

elements.content: Ongoing efforts are directed toward discovering other frameworks that display similar anion-exchange capabilities and robustness, allowing for transformations of biomass using mild conditions in aqueous media, besides investigating more complex lignin models. The present results demonstrate that postsynthetic anion exchange of metal–organic frameworks can be used to design catalysts with anion-dependent reactivity and selectivity through a judicious choice of the guest anion. The amalgamation of accessible open metal sites with confined spaces that provide a controlled reaction environment is highly promising in the development of next-generation heterogeneous catalysts.
elements.clean_text: Ongoing efforts are directed toward discovering other frameworks that display similar anion-exchange capabilities and robustness, allowing for transformations of biomass using mild conditions in aqueous media, besides investigating more complex lignin models. The present results demonstrate that postsynthetic anion exchange of metal-organic frameworks can be used to design catalysts with anion-dependent reactivity and selectivity through a judicious choice of the guest anion. The amalgamation of accessible open metal sites with confined spaces that provide a controlled reaction environment is highly promising in the development of next-generation heterogeneous catalysts.

cln_elements.content: (A) Structure of 1 viewed along the a-axis; blue = N, red = O, green = CuO5 square pyramidal geometry of the copper­(II) ions. The purple sphere highlights the spherical cavity present in 1 (about 13.2 Å in diameter). (B) Differences in the core motifs of the organic linkers found in 1 (viologen) and NOTT-102 (biphenyl). (C) Coordination environment of the dicopper paddlewheels, showing the exchange of water molecules in the apical position, thus providing accessible open metal sites for catalysis. The arrows represent the dissociation of coordinated water molecules.

cln_elements.content: (A) FT-IR spectra of as-synthesized 1 (NO3 –@1) and its anion-exchanged derivatives, highlighting selected bands of the corresponding anions. Inclusion of anions without any characteristic bands was monitored by the disappearance of the shoulder near 1300 cm–1 (highlighted green rectangle), assigned to an N–O asymmetric stretching vibration of the nitrate anion. (B) PXRD patterns of as-synthesized 1 and its anion-exchanged derivatives. (C) 15N magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) of 15NO3 –@1 before and after exchange with ClO4 – under the same spectroscopic conditions.
